section.heading: Scope.
section.text: This chapter applies to carriers that sell medical stop-loss insurance to small employers in Maryland.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
“Carrier” means an insurer or nonprofit health service plan that sells medical stop loss insurance in Maryland.
“Medical stop-loss insurance” has the meaning stated in Insurance Article, §15-129, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Medical stop-loss insurance disclosure form” means the form shown in Regulation .04 of this chapter.
“Small employer” has the meaning stated in Insurance Article, §31-101, Annotated Code of Maryland.

section.heading: Rules for Providing the Medical Stop-Loss Insurance Disclosure Form.

para.text: Before entering into a policy or contract of medical stop-loss insurance with a small employer, a carrier shall provide the small employer a completed medical stop-loss insurance disclosure form.

When determining whether an employer satisfies the definition of a small employer, the carrier shall base the determination on the definition that applies on the proposed effective date of the medical stop-loss insurance policy or contract.
The medical stop-loss insurance disclosure form shall be printed in at least 12-point type.
The portion of the medical stop-loss insurance disclosure form that requires a listing of any limitations in the medical stop-loss insurance policy or contract is required to include any:
Dollar limitations in the medical stop-loss insurance policy or contract, such as annual limitations;
Day or visit limits on the services covered under the medical stop-loss insurance policy or contract;
Limitations or exclusions that apply to benefits covered under the medical stop-loss insurance policy or contract, such as:
Exclusions or limitations for particular services, such as an exclusion or limitation for prescription drugs or mental health services;
Exclusions or limitations for particular medical conditions, such as AIDS;
Limitations or exclusions for non-medically necessary services; and
Limitations or exclusions for experimental or investigational services; and
Different attachment points for any particular service, such as organ transplants.
